posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
So I cannot seem to get Choreo to land at the setpoint I chose.  I’m constantly modifying PID values.  Overshooting then undershooting.  Second guessing whether 10, 10, 7 are fake numbers or the actual numbers.  Do these numbers scale with velocity.  When I use these numbers I get definite translation oscillation.  Going really slow 1mps.

I’m pulling my hair out (what little I have left chasing either error correction or setpoints.  What am I doing wrong?

Anyhoo.  Mild meltdown over.  Any help/thoughts would be appreciated.

auto-reorg branch

codebase

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Have you confirmed that the modules themselves are tracking with acceleration well?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: You’d have to plot the target and actual module speeds and see how well they match up. Without those plots, I couldn’t really advise on what to tune.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: There is a massive overshoot at the beginning which settles on.  But I can’t make it vanish no matter which no value I use.  I don’t know the order of magnitude for these values.  Limelight tracking is good.  Should I use a smaller motor torque?

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Here is a graph of trajectory velocity vs. actual field velocity in both x and y and omega Capture 1553×968 57.7 KB

Capture 1553×968 57.7 KB

Capture 1553×968 57.7 KB

Capture2 1557×952 39.7 KB

Capture2 1557×952 39.7 KB

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: I just added target field centric speeds.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: I can upload the wpilog if that will help

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: This is field speeds. I asked for wheel speeds. The actual control loops are on wheel velocity.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Sorry about that.

Capture 1561×979 50.3 KB

Capture 1561×979 50.3 KB

Capture 1561×979 50.3 KB

0 and 1 are good.

2 and 3 are also good.  Module States vs Target States

All similar to this graph in terms of tracking.  Almost perfect overlap

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Are you using Stop Point constraints on your path? The graph of trajectory vx/vy looks like it suddenly jumps to nonzero velocities.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Yes.  Stop points constraints are being used.  However these are just what appears when I create a new path.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Do the stop point constraints need to be set to the last two wayspoints.  say 1 and 2 if a simple path.  Or will Start/End work?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Start and End are what you should be using. Given that, I would guess the motor torque is too high. You might have put in stall torque, which is not achievable at speed. Try 0.4 N*m as a general starting point.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: I think that did it.  Near 2 or 3 cm off

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Also sorry for the mild spaz out

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Just curious, the rotation and translation, PID values should be the same regardless of Maximum path velocity used

posts.name: Michael Jiang
posts.cooked: We’re also having a similar issue where our robot consistently overshoots whenever we place a setpoint in the correct position, e.g. directly against the coral station. We’ve already turned the motor torque down to 0.75 N*m, and that helped a bit, but the robot still overshoots by ~5 inches. Any ideas of why this could be happening? Our code is here: GitHub - 4639RoboSpartans/2025-Heart-of-the-Sea

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Yes, those should be the same.
